section.title: Conservative Forces and Conservation of Energy

introduction.p:
What will happen if all forces acting on a body are conservartive forces? Work-energy theorem tells us that the net work done equals the change in the kinetic energy.
W_{if}^{\text{net}} = K_f - K_i.
But, if all forces are conservative, then the left side can also be written in terms of sum of the negative of potential energies of these forces.
\left( \sum U_i - \sum U_f \right) = K_f - K_i,
where \sum U_i is the sum of all U terms evaluated at instant t_i , and similarly for \sum U_f . Rearranging terms in this equation we get
K_i + \sum U_i = K_f + \sum U_i.
That is, if all the forces are conservative forces, then the combination K + \sum U is conserved and is independent of the path of the motion.

The combination K + \sum U is called energy and sometimes mechanical energy, and denoted by symbol E.
E = K + \sum U.
Equation can now be reexpressed as follows. If all forces acting on the body are conservative forces, then
E_i = E_f.
This is called the principle of conservation of energy, which we can state in words also.
Energy cannot change if only conservative forces act on the system.

exercise.title: The Energy of a Skier Going Down a Slope - Ignoring Drag and Kinetic Friciton Forces

statement.p: A skier starts near the top of a hill. His speed at a point on the slope that is 50\text{ m} above the sea level is 5.0\text{ m/s} .
What will be his speed when he reaches a point that is 35\text{ m} above the sea level, assuming you can neglect the effect of drag and kinetic fricion forces on the skier?

solution.p:
Ignoring Drag and Kinetic Friction forces, the forces on the skier are
Weight
Normal
The normal force will do no work since, at each instant, the normal force is perpendicular to the displacement. Thus, we have only a conservative force on the skier. Therefore, his energy cannot change.

Equating the energy of the skier at the two instants in the problem statement,
\dfrac{1}{2}mv_f^2 + mgy_f = \dfrac{1}{2}mv_i^2 + mgy_i.
The mass m cancels out. Solving for v_f we get
v_f = \sqrt{ v_i^2 + 2g(y_i - y_f) }.
Now, we put in the numbers.
v_f = \sqrt{ 5.0^2 + 2\times 9.81\times ( 50 - 35) } = 17.9\text{ m/s}.
